analytic.title: Journal Pre-proof Microstructure, mechanical properties and oxidation behavior of NbTaTi and NbTaZr refractory alloys

div.p: This is a PDF file of an article that has undergone enhancements after acceptance, such as the addition of a cover page and metadata, and formatting for readability, but it is not yet the definitive version of record. This version will undergo additional copyediting, typesetting and review before it is published in its final form, but we are providing this version to give early visibility of the article. Please note that, during the production process, errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Refractory complex concentrated alloys (RCCAs) have recently attracted much attention as promising structural materials due to vast, unexplored variations in alloy compositions with favorable combinations of elevated temperature mechanical properties, reduced density and improved oxidation resistance relative to conventional refractory alloys [1][2][3][4]. Due to their high J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f melting temperatures, these alloys have potential to operate at considerably higher temperatures than Ni-based superalloys. Use of Ni-based superalloys at temperatures above ~1000°C requires extensive cooling, which adds in operational cost, as these alloys become soft and melt at ~1250-1400°C. On the other hand, the melting temperatures of refractory alloys are much higher, and they have potential to operate and hold their strength at much higher temperatures. The densities and specific strengths of some of the reported RCCAs are also superior to the advanced Ni-based superalloys [2,3]. Recent analysis of mechanical properties of currently reported RCCAs showed that, while multi-phase RCCAs have extremely high strength at T ≤ 800-1000°C, singlephase RCCAs are generally stronger at T ≥ 1000-1200°C than the multi-phase RCCAs [4]. The rapid loss in strength of multi-phase RCCAs above ~800-1000°C was found to be a result of dissolution of secondary phases because of relatively low (≤ 1200°C) solvus temperatures. It was also found that all RCCAs show a strong decrease in their strength at temperatures above about 0.65T m , when diffusion-controlled softening processes start to dominate and solid solution strengthening diminishes [4]. Here T m is the absolute melting (solidus) temperature. Therefore, an RCCA with a higher melting temperature can keep its strength up to a higher absolute temperature. Taking into account that the RCCA melting temperature roughly follows the rule of mixture of the alloy components [4,5], this finding indicates that RCCAs consisting of the principal elements with higher melting points should keep their strength to higher temperatures than RCCAs containing lower melting point elements. Besides the melting temperature, the alloy microstructure and composition are also important for high-temperature strength.

Recent analysis of the composition and properties of the reported RCCAs shows that many of them contain equiatomic concentrations of NbTiZr, NbTaTi, NbTaZr and/or MoNbTi [3]. While the ternary NbTiZr and MoNbTi alloys are single-phase BCC structures, only few four-, fiveand six-component RCCAs based on these ternary systems are also single-phase BCC structures, while others contain two or more phases [3,6,7]. Moreover, the high-temperature strength of some four-and higher component RCCAs can be lesser than the strengths of ternary RCCAs on which these alloys are based [6][7][8]. Similar situation was also reported for 3-d transition FCC complex concentrated alloys (CCAs) containing Co, Cr, Fe, Ni and Mn [22], when a ternary CoCrNi CCA had better structural properties [23] than the quaternary CoCrFeNi or CoCrMnNi, and quinary CoCrFeMnNi equiatomic CCAs [9,10]. These results indicate that increasing the composition complexity and configurational entropy of CCAs by increasing the number of the J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f alloying elements does not necessary result in simpler phase structures and/or better mechanical properties. In agreement with classical metallurgy, the type of the alloying elements and phase stability in the temperature range of use are more important for high-temperature properties [6].

In this work, microstructure, phase composition, mechanical properties and oxidation behavior of two ternary equiatomic alloys, NbTaTi and NbTaZr, consisting of the elements, which are most often used in RCCAs, are extensively studied and reported. Their high-temperature properties are compared with the properties of earlier reported single-phase NbTiZr and MoNbTi and the effects of the alloying elements on the phase composition and properties of these ternary alloys are discussed.

div.head: EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES
div.p: The NbTaTi and NbTaZr were prepared by vacuum arc melting from the high purity (≥99.9%) elements. Each alloy was solidified inside a copper cavity, where it was prepared, and had a flattened cigar shape. After solidification, the alloy samples were wrapped in a Ta foil and hot isostatic pressed (HIP'd) under a hydrostatic pressure of a high purity argon of 210 MPa at 1400°C for 3 h. Heating and cooling rates were 15°C/min. The actual average alloy compositions were measured using direct current plasma atomic emission spectrometry (metals), inert gas fusion (oxygen and nitrogen) and combustion infrared absorption (carbon) methods, and the measurements are given in Table 1. The alloy densities were measured using a helium pycnometer and the average values from 10 measurements are given in Table 1. Microstructure, local chemical compositions and crystal structure of individual phases were studied using a field emission scanning electron microscope equipped with backscatter electron (BSE), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) and electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) detectors. Specimens for TEM analysis were prepared using a variation of the in-situ lift-out technique in a focused ion beam (FIB-SEM) [11]. High angle, annular dark field (STEM-HAADF) images and selected area diffraction patterns (SADPs) were captured at 200 kV, while EDS maps were acquired using a super-x (quad EDS) system. X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) was conducted using Cu K 1 radiation in the 2-Theta range of 10-120°. Compression mechanical tests were conducted in the temperature range of 20-1200°C at a constant ram speed that corresponded to the initial strain rate of 0.001 s -1 . The compression samples had a rectangular shape with dimensions 4.6 x 4.6 x 7.5 mm. Room temperature compression tests were conducted in air and high-temperature tests were J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f conducted in vacuum of ~2x10 -3 Pa, at a constant ram speed, which corresponded to the initial strain rate of 0.001 s -1 . The temperature setting for high-temperature compression testing consisted of heating at 50°C/min to a test temperature, holding at the temperature for 15 min, deformation with 50% height reduction (or until fracture, if it occurred first) and cooling at the initial cooling rate of 100°C/min or the rate of furnace cooling when the power was shut off, whichever was slower. A detailed description of the experimental procedures is given elsewhere [12]. The samples were placed in 3YSZ (yttria-stabilized zirconia) crucibles, inserted into the furnace preheated to 1200°C, held for pre-selected times and air quenched from the temperature at the end of the oxidation periods. Post oxidation crystallographic and microstructural analysis was conducted in a similar fashion as previously described. However, for X-ray diffraction, oxide scales were separated from the surface of the oxidized material, when it was possible, and ground into powder; otherwise, the XRD patterns were captured from the oxidized free surfaces.

div.head: Mechanical Properties
div.p: True stress vs. true strain compression curves of NbTaTi and NbTaZr obtained at different temperatures are shown in Figure 1. Plastic deformation of both alloys began with a noticeable stress increase. The strain-induced hardening effect slowed down with increasing strain, the flow stress reached its peak value and then plastic deformation occurred at a constant or continuously decreasing stress. The yield stress (σ y ) and peak stress (σ p ) values registered in the alloys at different temperatures are given in Table 2. The true peak strains (ε p ) at which the respective true peak stresses approached at different temperatures are also given in Table 2. The temperature J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f dependences of σ y and σ p are shown in Figure 2. NbTaZr was stronger than NbTaTi at all studied temperatures. For example, σ y of NbTaZr was about 40% higher at 25°C and about twice higher at 400-800°C. The yield stress difference between the two alloys decreased noticeably with increasing temperature beyond 600°C (Figure 2a). NbTaTi showed slightly higher strain hardening than NbTaZr (Figure 1), which resulted in the peak stress difference to be smaller than the yield stress difference (Figure 2b, Table 2). NbTaTi had excellent ductility at all studied temperatures and it did not show any evidence of fracture during compression deformation with true strains up to 0.65. On the other hand, NbTaZr fractured during deformation at 25-600°C
after true plastic strains of ~0.15-0.25 (Figure 1). No fracture of this alloy occurred at higher temperatures.

div.head: Annealed (HIP'd) Condition
div.p: Both NbTaTi and NbTaZr have near equiatomic compositions and their densities are 10.09±0.01 g/cm 3 and 10.30±0.01 g/cm 3 , respectively (Table 1). X-ray diffraction analysis of NbTaTi identified diffraction peaks from a single BCC phase, with the lattice parameter a = 328.5 pm (Figure 3a). Diffraction peaks from two BCC phases, BCC1 and BCC2, were present on the Xray diffraction patterns from NbTaZr (Figure 3b). The lattice parameters of these phases were determined to be very close to each other: a BCC1 = 332.0 pm and a BCC2 = 335.4 pm. Smallintensity diffraction peaks from minor phases were also present, which could be assigned to an HCP phase with the lattice parameters a HCP = 320.4 pm and c HCP = 509.4 pm, and an FCC phase with a FCC = 506.5 pm (Figure 3b). The measured lattice parameters of the HCP phase are similar to that of α-Zr (a Zr = 322.94 pm and c Zr = 514.14 pm) [13], while the measured lattice parameter of the FCC phase is close to the reported lattice parameter of cubic zirconium oxides: Zr 2 O (a=508.8 pm) [14], ZrO (a=511.0 pm) [15] or ZrO 2 (a=494.7 pm) [16].

J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f The microstructure of NbTaTi after HIP consisted of coarse, polygonal grains of ~0.4 mm in diameter (Figure 4a). Adjacent grains were separated by straight grain boundaries, indicating well annealed condition. Higher magnification images revealed precipitation of secondary phases, both inside grains and at grain boundaries (Figure 4b). Precipitation-free regions were present along areas adjacent to grain boundary precipitates. The average thickness of these precipitate-free regions, inside each grain, was about 2 µm. An EBSD analysis showed that the matrix phase and intra-granular precipitates have BCC crystal structures, while the grain boundary precipitates have an FCC crystal structure (Figure 4c). According to EDS analysis, the second-phase precipitates were rich in Ti and depleted in Nb and Ta (Figure 5, Table 3), which is in agreement with their dark appearance on BSE images. The interstitial elements were distributed evenly between the matrix and intra-granular particles; however, the grain-boundary precipitates had an increasing amount of N and decreasing amount of C (Figure 5). It is likely that the increased amount of N in the grain boundary precipitates is responsible for their FCC crystal structure [17,18]. The volume fraction of the Ti-rich second phases was ~13.1%. Since the X-ray diffraction pattern from NbTaTi showed the diffraction peaks from a single BCC phase only, it is likely that the lattice parameters of the BCC matrix phase and the BCC Ti-rich precipitates are similar. The volume fraction of grain-boundary precipitates with the FCC crystal structure is small, ~1%, and the diffraction peaks from this phase are likely shielded by the background X-ray diffraction intensity. The microstructure of NbTaZr was very different from that of NbTaTi. It consisted of finer equiaxed grains of ~40 µm in diameter (Figure 6a). Coarse, needle-like or plate-like, dark second-phase particles were present at grain boundaries, some of which propagated inside the grains. The grain interior consisted of the nano-lamellar mixture of two co-continuous phases (Figure 6b,c). EDS maps revealed that the nano-lamellae, which looked dark on the BSE images, were rich with Zr and depleted in Nb and Ta, while the nano-lamellae, which looked brighter on the BSE images, were rich in Nb and Ta (Figure 7). It was not possible to identify exact chemical compositions of these BCC nano-lamellar phases, as the electron beam excitation area was larger than the lamellar thickness. In average, these intragranular regions were rich in Ta and depleted in Zr (Table 4). EDS analysis also showed that dark coarse particles at grain boundaries were rich in Zr and O (Figure 7, Table 4). It is quite possible that these coarse particles were present during HIP at 1400°C, together with the matrix phase, thus preventing the matrix grains to grow and explaining the relatively low grain size in this alloy. The volume fraction of the coarse, Zr-rich particles was estimated to be ~5-8%.

J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f A TEM analysis was also used to study the fine and complex microstructure of the NbTaZr alloy. A thin foil was extracted from a region containing both nano-lamellae of Ta and Zr rich phases and coarse, plate-like Zr-rich particles (Figure 8). The TEM-EDS analysis showed that the Ta-rich lamellae are actually a continuous matrix phase with the composition shown in Table 5. The fine lamellae inside the matrix are rich in Zr, but they also contain relatively large amount (~40.2%) of Nb and Ta. Coarse, plate-like particles are heavily enriched in Zr (~85.5%, Table 5), in agreement with SEM/EDS analysis. The detected amounts of N and O are in the range of 0.1 -3.3% and 1.8 -2.9%, respectively, with the lowest amount in the Ta-rich matrix and higher To determine crystal structures of the phases, a series of selected area diffraction patterns (SADPs) were taken from (i) a region containing the Ta-rich and Zr-rich nano-lamellar phases only (Figure 9) and (ii) from a Zr-rich coarse particle (Figure 10). All the SADPs collected from the nano-lamellar region were identified to belong to a BCC crystal structure with the lattice parameter a = 333.2 pm. For example, Figure 9

div.head: Microstructure after Compression Deformation at 1000°C
div.p: Compression deformation of NbTaTi at 1000°C resulted in noticeable elongation of grains and formation of characteristic striations in the directions inclined about 60-70° to the compression direction (Figure 11a). Higher magnification images showed that the Ti-rich second-phase particles became preferably oriented in the direction of the plastic flow (Figure 11b) and many particles became round-shaped. Subgrain structure formed inside deformed grains (Figure 11c).

The average subgrain diameter was ~1.4 µm inside grains and it decreased to ~ 1.0 µm in the vicinity of former grain boundaries (Figure 11c). After compression deformation at 1000°C of NbTaZr, initially equiaxed grains became elongated and many plate-like Zr-rich second phase particles located at grain boundaries became oriented in the directions of plastic flow (Figure 12a). The nano-lamellar structure, which was present inside grains in undeformed samples, coarsened and partially transformed to a mixture of globular-like particles (Figure 12b).

div.head: CALPHAD Analysis
div.p: Equilibrium phase diagrams of the NbTaTi and NbTaZr alloys calculated with the use of PanNb2018 thermodynamic database and Pandat 2018 software are shown in Figure 13.

According to these calculations, NbTaTi solidifies between T l = 2342°C and T m = 2163°C to a single BCC phase, which partially transforms to a Ti-rich (~98 at.% Ti, 0.7 Nb, 1.3 Ta) HCP phase below 549°C (Figure 13a). The volume fraction of the HCP phase is predicted to be 13%

J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f at 500°C, which is similar to the experimentally observed volume fraction of Ti-rich secondphase precipitates in this alloy (Figure 4). The experiment, however, shows noticeably larger amount of Nb and Ta in the second phase (Table 3), which can be explained by insufficient diffusion of these elements during phase transformation. Being BCC stabilizers, Nb and Ta prevent transformation of the Ti-rich particles to the hexagonal structure. Instead, a secondary, metastable Ti-rich BCC phase forms at ambient conditions. is rich in Zr (Figure 13b). The calculations also demonstrate that all the BCC2 phase should experience monotectoid transformation to a Zr-rich HCP phase and Nb and Ta rich BCC1 phase at 698°C (Figure 13b). The experimental results, however, disagree with the calculated diagram.

They show that the alloy retains a large amount of the Zr-rich BCC phase (nano-lamellae) and also contains a Zr-rich HCP phase in the form of coarse, needle-like or plate-like particles located at and near grain boundaries (Figure 6, Figure 8). It is likely that these coarse particles were present during HIP at 1400°C thus restricting grain growth at this temperature. One may therefore suggest that partial decomposition of the high-temperature BCC phase in the NbTaZr alloy starts at temperatures above 1400°C by the formation of a Zr-rich HCP phase. Below 1400 o C (the exact temperature needs to be identified in additional experiments), the remaining J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f BCC phase experiences separation in two BCC phases, one of which is rich in Nb and Ta and another is rich in Zr. It is likely that the observed phase composition is metastable and long-time annealing is needed to approach equilibrium. The presence of a rather large amount of interstitial elements in the alloy may also affect the sequence of phase reactions as it is known that dissolved O and N stabilize the HCP structure in Zr alloys and extend its presence to higher temperatures [20][21][22].

div.head: Oxidation
div.p: Oxidation behaviors of the NbTaTi and NbTaZr alloys were investigated at 1200°C in air.

Figure 14 shows specific mass gain (Δm, normalized with respect to initial surface area) versus time t for each alloy. The oxidation behavior of NbTaTi and NbTaZr alloys can be described by a general oxide growth rate law:

where k is the oxide growth rate constant and n is the time exponent. The k and n values fitted to the studied alloys are given in Table 6. The NbTaTi alloy is depicted with one-time regime, while NbTaZr was calculated considering two different time regimes for comparison. oxidation data for two commercial refractory alloys, C-3009 (Nb-20Hf-6W, at.%) [23] and C-103 (Nb-5.4Hf-2.0Ti-0.7Zr-0.3Ta-0.3W, at.%) [24], are also plotted for comparison.

The near-linear specific mass gain for NbTaTi indicates that the oxidation of this alloy proceeds via interface limited mechanism. This behavior proceeds out to 24 hours followed by a drop in the rate of oxidation between 24 and 48 hours. This slowdown is predominately due to the significant change in surface area compared to the original sample geometrya small pellet is all that remained after 48 hours. Based on microstructural observations and X-ray diffraction, a fine mixture of Ti(Nb,Ta) 2 O 7 and Ti 2 (Nb,Ta) 10 O 29 formed uniformly on the sample surface at all times examined, Figure 15 and Figure 17 6, this response can be described by near parabolic behavior, indicating a diffusion limited oxidation mechanism. Beyond 8 hours, the oxidation rate of NbTaZr appeared to slow down and after 24 hours the specific mass gain of this alloy was only slightly higher than that of NbTaTi. As described for NbTaTi, it is likely that the large decrease in the oxidation rate between 8 and 24 hours for the NbTaZr alloy was also due to substantial oxide formation and limited base metal remaining for subsequent reaction. After 24 hours of exposure, the NbTaZr alloy had completely transformed to oxides, likely facilitating minimal mass gain between 8 and 24 hours with respect to initial surface area. Microstructural and XRD analysis revealed that a mixture of orthorhombic and tetragonal polymorphs of (Nb,Ta J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The equimolar alloys, NbTaTi and NbTaZr, studied in this work represent two ternary components, which are commonly observed, together with NbTiZr [7] and MoNbTi [12], in refractory high entropy alloys (RHEAs) with a single-phase BCC crystal structure [3], such as NbTaTiZr [34], HfNbTaTiZr [35,36] and HfMoNbTaTiZr [37], as well as in many multi-phase RCCAs [3]. While ternary NbTiZr and MoNbTi alloys are also single-phase BCC structures, NbTaTi consists of a BCC1 matrix and Ti-rich BCC2 precipitates, and NbTaZr consists of a nano-lamellar mixture of two BCC phases, one of which is rich in Nb and Ta and another is rich in Zr. A small fraction of Ti and N-rich FCC phase in NbTaTi and Zr-rich HCP phase in NbTaZr is also detected at or near grain boundaries.

Formation of the secondary BCC phases in NbTaTi and NbTaZr is likely due to the presence of Ta, which has high repulsive interactions with Ti and Zr in a certain temperature and composition ranges [38][39][40]. Indeed, the refractory elements Nb and Ta belong to subgroup V of the periodic table and form a continuous BCC solid solution [41,42]. J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f solutions with Nb and Ta at high temperatures. At lower temperatures, in accord to the currently available experimental data and CALPHAD database trained on this data [41,42], a two-phase, BCC+HCP, region is present in Nb-Ti, Ta-Ti and Nb-Ta-Ti systems, with the solvus temperature decreasing with increasing the concentrations of Nb and Ta. For example, our CALPHAD calculations predict formation of the hexagonal phase in the equimolar NbTaTi below ~549°C.

At the same time, recent ab-initio calculations of the Ta-Ti phase diagram predict a miscibility gap in the BCC phase region, at Ta concentrations higher than 40 at.%, which results in the formation of two BCC phases, one is rich in Ti and another is rich in Ta [40]. It is possible that the Ti-rich BCC2 phase observed in NbTaTi is related to the predicted immiscibility between Ta and Ti. A relatively low temperature of the BCC to HCP phase transformation in this alloy, at which diffusion of Nb and Ta is extremely low, can also be the reason of the formation of the Tirich BCC phase in NbTaTi. Indeed, in accord to the CALPHAD analysis, the equilibrium HCP phase contains very small amount (less than 2.5% in total) of Nb and Ta. These equilibrium concentrations between the phases are achieved by diffusion and require very long time at temperatures below 600°C. Therefore, experimental observation of the Ti-rich BCC2 phase, which contains rather large amount (from 26 to 48%) of Nb and Ta (Table 3), can be explained by insufficient diffusion of these elements during the phase transformation. Being BCC stabilizers, Nb and Ta prevent transformation of the Ti-rich particles to the hexagonal structure.
Instead, a secondary, metastable Ti-rich BCC2 phase forms at ambient conditions.
Relatively large amounts of O and N results in the formation of grain-boudary Ti-rich FCC precipitates in NbTaTi. It is known that TiN and TiO can have the FCC crystal structure [17,43].

However, recently a FCC phase was also reported in a commercially pure Ti after cold working [44] or mechanical attrition [45], as well as in powder metallurgy Ti-8Mo-6Fe synthesized after ball milling in high-purity nitrogen atmosphere [46]. It is likely that formation of the FCC phase in all these cases is coincided with the interaction of Ti with O and/or N; however, it is not yet identified if such interactions form FCC oxides [17,43] or a new FCC crystal structure of O and N solid solutions in Ti can be present under certain conditions [44][45][46].

The binary Nb-Zr and Ta-Zr systems have well defined miscibility gaps in the BCC temperature range of 620-977°C and 800-1760°C, respectively, at concentrations of Nb between 19 and 92.2 at.% or Ta between 6.5 and 91 at.% [41]. Previous work indicates that the phase separation in the miscibility gap region can occur by a spinodal decomposition [47,48]. The BCC phase J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f separation, sometimes followed by atomic ordering of the Zr-rich BCC phase, was also observed in several Ta-Zr containing RCCAs [49][50][51][52]. There is therefore no surprise that the miscibility gap is also present in the ternary Nb-Ta-Zr alloy system. A specific nano-lamellar morphology of the Zr-rich BCC2 in the Ta-rich BCC1 continuous matrix, with the same crystallographic orientations and similar lattice parameters of both phases, suggests that these two phases formed by spinodal decomposition of the high-temperature BCC phase in the NbTaZr alloy. A small (~1.0%) difference in the lattice parameters and the same crystallographic orientation of the BCC1 and BCC2 phases also indicate that these phases a coherent. In addition to the main BCC1 and BCC2 phases, NbTaZr also contain a small fraction (~5-8%) of coarse, plate-like Zr-rich particles of the HCP phase, which are located at or near grain boundaries and which are also enriched with interstitial elements. A much finer grain size in NbTaZr than in NbTaTi suggests that these precipitates were present in the alloy during HIP at 1400°C and were effective obstacles against grain growth. It is likely that O and N being HCP stabilizing elements in Zr alloys triggered partial decomposition of the high-temperature BCC phase and formation of Zrrich coarse precipitates above 1400°C, as discussed in section 3.3.
The microstructural and phase analysis suggests that the BCC phases in HIP'd NbTaTi and

NbTaZr are likely metastable and correspond to incomplete phase transformations due to considerably reduced diffusion of Nb and Ta at temperatures below ~900°C. In the case of NbTaTi this produces a non-equilibrium Ti-rich BCC phase stabilized with Nb and Ta, instead of the equilibrium HCP phase deficient in Nb and Ta. In the case of NbTaZr, this preserves a Nb and Ta stabilized Zr-rich high-temperature BCC2 phase.

Different microstructure and phase composition are likely responsible for the different deformation behavior of the studied alloys. At all the studied temperatures the NbTaTi alloy consisting of a continuous disordered BCC matrix and discontinuous, Ti-rich, submicron-sized precipitates is more ductile but softer than the NbTaZr alloy, which has a spinodally decomposed microstructure consisting of two coherent BCC phases (Figure 2). These multi-phase structures retain on heating to at least 1200°C (see Figure 11, Figure 12, Figure 15, Figure 16). The compression ductility of NbTaZr improves considerably, accompanying with a noticeable drop in the yield stress, at temperatures above ~600°C (Figure 2). Such a perceptible change in the mechanical behavior of NbTaZr above 600°C is likely due to the transformation of a stronger nano-lamellar structure to a globular one (Figure 12). To visualize the effect of alloy chemical J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f composition and phase composition on the yield stress and its temperature dependence in the ternary equiatomic alloys, the behavior of the studied alloys is compared with the behavior of earlier reported single-phase BCC alloys, NbTiZr [7] and MoNbTi [12] (Figure 18). It can be seen that replacing Zr in the single-phase BCC NbTiZr alloy with Ta causes not only precipitation of the Ti-rich phase but also a considerable decrease in the yield stress at temperatures < 1000°C. However, such substitution of Zr with Ta is beneficial for increasing the strength at T ≥ 1000°C. The higher strength of NbTiZr than NbTaTi at T < 1000°C is likely due to at least two reasons. First, a considerably larger atomic radius of Zr (r Zr = 160 pm) than the atomic radius of Ta (r Ta = 143 pm), which is similar to the atomic radii of Nb (r Nb = 143 pm) and Ti (r Ti = 146 pm), should produce larger crystal lattice distortions and higher solid solution strengthening. Secondly, precipitation of the Ti-rich phase in NbTaTi results in dilution of the matrix phase with Ti and a decrease in the solid solution strengthening effect from this element;

while the strengthening contribution from relatively large precipitates may not compensate this decrease. At higher temperatures, however, NbTaTi becomes stronger because it has higher absolute melting temperature (T m ) while the solid solution strengthening effect decreases rapidly at temperatures above ~0.6T m [4]. Indeed, the solidus temperatures (T m ) of NbTaTi and NbTiZr are 2163°C (2436K) and 1688°C (1961K), respectively, and the solid solution strengthening can effectively operate in these alloys only at temperatures below 1186°C (1462K) and 904°C (1177K), respectively.

Comparison of the temperature dependence of the yield stress of the NbTiZr and NbTaZr alloys shows that the NbTaZr alloy is stronger at all the studied temperatures (Figure 18a). This indicates that replacing Ti with Ta is beneficial for increasing strength in these alloy systems.

The higher yield stress of the NbTaZr alloy is likely due to its multi-phase, spinodal structure at these temperatures (Figure 13b). However, NbTaZr has higher density (10.3 g/cm 3 ) than NbTiZr (6.63 g/cm 3 ). This causes the specific stress of NbTiZr to be higher than that of NbTaZr up to 800°C. At higher temperatures, the specific strength of NbTaZr becomes higher because of the drop of solid solution strengthening in NbTiZr (Figure 18b).
The behavior of the studied alloys, NbTaTi and NbTaZr, is also compared with the behavior of a single-phase-BCC MoNbTi (Figure 18). It can be found from the comparison of NbTaTi and
MoNbTi that Mo has a considerably higher strengthening effect than Ta at all the studied temperatures. Similar observation was reported earlier on other high-entropy alloy systems [53].
J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f

Comparison of NbTiZr and MoNbTi also indicates that the strengthening effects from Zr and Mo are almost similar at temperatures up to 600°C, but at higher temperatures Mo makes alloy stronger. The beneficial effect of Mo comes from its smaller atomic radius (r Mo = 136 pm) causing effective solution strengthening, high melting temperature (T m of MoNbTi is 2388K [4])

and much lower density than Ta. As the result, the specific yield stress of MoNbTi, which density is 7.67 g/cm 3 , is noticeably higher than that of NbTaTi and NbTaZr, especially at high temperatures (Figure 18b).

Finally, it is worth to point out that the yield stress and specific yield stress of the studied ternary alloys are noticeably higher than the respective properties of a commercial refractory alloy C-103, which is currently used in several aerospace structures (Figure 18). This opens up an opportunity of producing a new generation of stronger and less expensive refractory alloys, than the refractory alloys which are currently in service [12].

Figure 18. Temperature dependence of (a) the yield stress and (b) specific yield stress of the studied two-phase alloys, NbTaTi and NbTaZr, and previously reported single-phase BCC alloys NbTiZr [7] and MoNbTi [12], and a commercial alloy C-103 (Nb-5.4Hf-2.0Ti-0.7Zr-0.3Ta-0.3W, by at.%) [12]. J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f These findings reiterate that the complex oxides observed in this work, and the work of others, are non-protective in nature and should be avoided [25,28]. For comparison, Figure 14 shows 1200℃ oxidation data for two commercial Nb-based alloys, C-3009 (Nb-20Hf-6W, at.%) and C-103 (Nb-5.4Hf-2.0Ti-0.7Zr-0.3Ta-0.3W, at.%). In particular, within the first few hours the NbTaZr alloy displays oxidation kinetics quite similar to C-103, which from a mass gain standpoint, both are inferior to the oxidation behaviors of NbTaTi and C-3009. The NbTaTi and C-3009 alloys display similar oxidation response up to 8 hrs, but C-3009 exhibits better behavior for longer durations. This superior response of C-3009 is likely due to the high concentration of Hf and absence of Ta, when compared to NbTaTi. Nevertheless, oxidation resistance of both NbTaTi and NbTaZr is better than that of C-103, especially at longer annealing times (Figure 14). Mitigation of the poor oxidation performance of NbTaTi and NbTaZr alloys can be achieved through systematic compositional changes, as reported in the works of others investigating the oxidation behaviors of more complex alloys [3].
While NbTaZr oxidized faster than NbTaTi, it did not exhibit extensive spalling during cooling.

This indicates that the oxides that formed on NbTaZr may experience less interfacial stress with the underlying alloy during oxidation. This also aligns well with the observation of cracking in the NbTaTi alloy and minimal cracking in the NbTaZr alloy, Figure 15 and Figure 16. This behavior may also be due to the strong preference for internal oxidation (e.g. inward diffusion of oxygen) that was observed for the NbTaZr alloy, which mimicked the starting microstructure.

However, both alloys suffered from some extent of internal reaction with oxidation, which demonstrates again, the necessity of alloying elements that can help prevent the ingress of light elements into the metallic substrate if mechanical properties are to be maintained in high temperature oxidizing environments.

Due to the significant reduction in remaining metal alloy (e.g. surface area) during prolonged oxidation exposure of NbTaTi and NbTaZr, it is suggested that mass gain data for complex refractory alloys be carefully interpreted. Using kinetic data alone can lead to misleading oxidation performance results. In cases where rapid oxidation kinetics is observed, an alternative "continuous" surface area may prove to be more useful; this has been suggested previously by Mrowec and Stoklosa amongst others [54]. In addition, complimentary measurements and analysis (e.g. depth profiles, oxygen ingress, etc.) are highly beneficial in the interpretation of oxidation behavior. NbTiZr [7] and MoNbTi [11].

figure.head: Figure 14 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 14. Oxidation behavior of NbTaTi and NbTaZr during holding in air at 1200°C. 1200℃ oxidation data for two commercial refractory alloys, C-3009 (Nb-20Hf-6W, at.%)[23] and C-103 (Nb-5.4Hf-2.0Ti-0.7Zr-0.3Ta-0.3W, at.%)[24], are also plotted for comparison.

(a). These oxides are known to be non-protective in other refractory materials[25][26][27]. Nb-Ti and Ta-Ti alloys are known to form these compounds with very similar lattice parameters; it is therefore assumed that Nb and Ta are present in these compounds interchangeably. The scale suffered extensive spalling during cooling. The metallic substrate also exhibited considerable, fine-scale internal oxidation/nitridation approximately 80 μm deep after 1 hour and hundreds of microns deep upon longer periods, Figure 15(b). After one hour, a normalized mass gain of 2.6 mg/cm 2 was observed, which is superior to that of a 50/50 NbTi alloy observed by Parida et al. at 1050°C for 1 hour [28]. By 4 hours, however, a normalized mass gain of 40.3 mg/cm 2 was observed, confirming the non-protective nature of the J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f oxide scale. The NbTaTi alloy exhibited limited evolution in the internal microstructure, as evident by Figure 15(c), which shows the internal "core" of the alloy after oxidation at 1200°C for 8 hours. The oxidation behavior of NbTaZr displayed an accelerated regime of transient oxidation during the first hour of oxidation, after which the rate of Δm change decreased and followed an almost linear trend up to 8 hours. As shown in Table

) 2 O 5 along with (Nb,Ta) 2 Zr 6 O 17 formed on the surface, with the initial scale microstructure reflecting that of the starting metal substrate, indicating oxidation occurring primarily by inward diffusion of oxygen, Figure 16(a)-(b) and Figure 17(b). The formation of the pentoxide is not too surprising, since Nb and Ta both prefer the formation of this particular oxide. It is also assumed that Nb and Ta substitute on the cation sublattice, since they share the same group on the periodic table. The mixed oxide (e.g. (Nb,Ta) 2 Zr 6 O 17 ) is also consistent with what is generally observed for Nb 2 O 5 -ZrO 2 and Ta 2 O 5 -ZrO 2 systems[29][30][31][32]. Similar to the NbTaTi alloy, the NbTaZr alloy also exhibited an internal reaction zone containing a fine-scale oxide/nitride product, Figure16(a)-(b). However, no spalling of the oxide scale was observed upon cooling for the NbTaZr alloy. With prolonged oxidation exposure, the orthorhombic polymorph of (Nb,Ta) 2 O 5 appeared to dominate in the XRD patterns, which is expected as this is the low temperature form, present below approximately 1300°C after sufficiently long annealing timesthe tetragonal phase is metastable above approximately 950°C[32,33]. As was the case for the NbTaTi alloy, the internal microstructure of the NbTaZr alloy exhibited only minimal transformation after oxidation at 1200°C for 8 hours, Figure16(c).

figure.head: Figure 15 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 15. SEM cross sectional images of NbTaTi after oxidation at 1200°C for 8 hours (a) and inset higher magnification image of oxide/internal reaction zone interface (b) and microstructure of the center of the alloy core (c).

figure.head: Figure 16 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 16. SEM cross sectional images of NbTaZr after oxidation at 1200°C for 8 hours (a) and inset higher magnification image of oxide/internal reaction zone interface (b) and microstructure of the center of the alloy core (c).

NbTaTi and NbTaZr both exhibit rapid oxidation kinetics at 1200°C in air. This is not unexpected, as high concentrations of refractory elements like Nb and Ta tend to promote the formation of deleterious oxides (e.g. Nb 2 O 5 , Ta 2 O 5 ). In addition, refractory alloys are known to display unfavorable oxidation kinetics at high temperatures without the addition of elements like Al and/or Cr that facilitate the formation of more protective oxides (e.g. Al 2 O 3 , Cr 2 O 3 , NbCrO 4 ).

note.p: Specimens measuring 4.6 mm x 4.6 mm x 7.5 mm were also prepared for oxidation tests. Prior to testing, the sample surfaces were ground to at least 600 grit with silicon carbide paper and ultrasonically cleaned with soapy water, distilled water, acetone, and finally ethanol. Oxidation testing was performed in an open air box furnace at 1200°C for times varying between 1 hour and 48 hours.

The substitution of Ti with Ta makes the alloys stronger at all the studied temperatures. Mo has a stronger strengthening effect than Ta at T =25 -1200°C and stronger than Zr at T ≥ 800°C.
